culturalNote: Most common informal greeting in Shona
Used to show respect, especially to elders

usageExample: Makadii? Ndiri nani. (How are you? I am fine.)

culturalNote: Used until around noon
Literally means 'remain well'
Traditional way to wish someone a safe journey

context: Term of respect for father or elderly man
culturalNote: Also used as respectful title for any older man

context: Term of respect for mother or elderly woman
culturalNote: Also used as respectful title for any older woman
Shows respect for older male sibling
Term of great respect for elderly men
Term of great respect for elderly women
Important position in traditional family structure
Also means 'courage' or 'spirit'

back: staple food made from maize meal
culturalNote: National staple food of Zimbabwe

usageExample: Ndiri kuenda kuchikoro (I am going to school)

culturalNote: Same word for 'want' and 'love'

usageExample: Ndiri kudya sadza (I am eating sadza)
Ndinoda kunwa mvura (I want to drink water)
Ndichauya neMuvhuro (I will come on Monday)
Ndakatarisira Chitatu (I'm looking forward to Wednesday)

culturalNote: Traditional day of rest and church
usageExample: Svondo ndichaenda kuchechi (On Sunday I'll go to church)
Ndiri kuenda kuchikoro (I am going to school)
Ndinoda kuenda kuchipatara (I want to go to the hospital)
Amai vari kumusika (Mother is at the market)
Tinoenda kuchechi neSvondo (We go to church on Sunday)
Zita rangu ndinoMunashe (My name is Munashe)

culturalNote: Very polite way to ask for help
usageExample: Ndinokumbirawo rubatsiro nekufema (I kindly request help with breathing)

culturalNote: Often expressed communally in Shona culture
usageExample: Ndiri kushungurudzika nekurasikirwa (I am sad about the loss)
Ndinofunga kuti zvakanaka kudzidza chiShona (I think it's good to learn Shona)
Handinyatsoziva kuti zvichaitika sei (I'm not quite sure how it will happen)

back: Perhaps we can help each other
culturalNote: Reflects the spirit of ubuntu
usageExample: Pamwe tinogona kubatsirana nebasa iri (Perhaps we can help each other with this work)

back: I was surprised to see you here
usageExample: Ndakashamisika nekuona iwe pano mangwanani (I was surprised to see you here this morning)

back: We must think about the future
usageExample: Tinofanira kufunga nezveramangwana revana (We must think about the children's future)
Ndinobvumirana newe zvachose pamusoro penyaya iyi (I agree with you completely on this matter)

culturalNote: Polite way to disagree without direct confrontation
usageExample: Handifungi kudaro, asi ndinonzwa zvaunotaura (I don't think so, but I hear what you're saying)
Regai ndifunge nezvazvo ndichakuudzai mangwana (Let me think about it, I'll tell you tomorrow)
Dambudziko iri chakatangira kupi? (Where did this problem start from?)
Zviri pachena kuti hatikwanisi kupedza basa iri nhasi (It's clear we cannot finish this work today)

back: My view is that we need to plan
culturalNote: Formal way to express opinion in meetings
usageExample: Maonero angu ndeekuti tinofanira kuronga zvakanaka (My view is that we need to plan well)

back: Even so, we don't give up
culturalNote: Expresses resilience valued in Shona culture
usageExample: Kunyangwe zvakadaro, hatiregeri kurwira kodzero dzedu (Even so, we don't give up fighting for our rights)

back: In other words, we need strength
usageExample: Nemamwe mazwi, tinoda simba rekuenderera mberi (In other words, we need strength to continue)

back: One finger cannot crush a louse
culturalNote: Emphasizes the importance of cooperation and unity
usageExample: Ngatibastirane, chara chimwe hachitswanyi inda (Let's work together, one finger cannot crush a louse)

culturalNote: Emphasizes patience and careful planning
usageExample: Funga zvakanaka, kukurumidza hakusi kukunda (Think carefully, hurrying is not winning)

back: What covers houses is the roof
culturalNote: Emphasizes that families should keep private matters within the home
usageExample: Musataura zvemumba kunze, chakafukidza dzimba matenga (Don't talk about home matters outside, what covers houses is the roof)

back: To have patience (lit: to have a long heart)
culturalNote: Important virtue in Shona culture
usageExample: Iva nemoyo murefu, zvinhu zvichaitika (Have patience, things will happen)

back: To tighten one's belt (lit: to put teeth in stomach)
culturalNote: Refers to enduring hardship or hunger
usageExample: Tinofanira kuisa mazino nedumbu kusvika mamiriro achinja (We must tighten our belts until things improve)

culturalNote: Traditional sign of respect and gratitude
usageExample: Vanhu vakapenya maoko vachifara (People clapped their hands with joy)
Zuva rinopisa zvikuru nhasi (The sun is very hot today)
Kunotonhora mangwanani (It's cold in the morning)

culturalNote: Cattle are highly valued in Shona culture
Symbol of strength and bravery
usageExample: Shumba ishiri yesango (The lion is the king of the forest)

culturalNote: Symbol of wisdom and power

usageExample: Mutengo uri wechingwa? (How much is the bread?)
Hembe iyi inodhura zvakadini? (How much does this shirt cost?)
Ndinorwara, ndinoda kuenda kuchipatara (I am sick, I want to go to the hospital)
Musoro wangu unorwadza zvikuru (My head hurts a lot)
Ndine fivha uye kuhotera (I have a fever and chills)
Harare iri chamhembe (Harare is to the north)
South Africa iri maodzanyemba (South Africa is to the south)

culturalNote: Literally means 'where the sun rises'
usageExample: Mozambique iri kumabvazuva (Mozambique is to the east)
Botswana iri kumadokero (Botswana is to the west)
Amai vangu mudzidzisi (My mother is a teacher)
Ndinoda kuva chiremba (I want to be a doctor)

culturalNote: Farming is highly respected in Shona culture
usageExample: Baba vangu murimi (My father is a farmer)
Ndinofara zvikuru kukuonai (I am very happy to see you)
Usatsamwe nazvo (Don't be angry about it)
Ndinotya rima (I am afraid of darkness)
Ndakakwira bhazi (I got on the bus)
Ndiri kushandisa intaneti (I am using the internet)

culturalNote: Central to traditional Shona spirituality
Supreme deity in Shona traditional religion and Christianity
Important marriage custom in Shona culture
usageExample: Baba vanotenga roora (Father is paying lobola)

culturalNote: Place where community matters are discussed
usageExample: Vanhu vakaunganira kudare (People gathered at the dare)

culturalNote: Sacred instrument used in ceremonies

back: If I had known, I would have come
usageExample: Dai ndaiziva kuti uri pano, ndingadai ndakauya (If I had known you were here, I would have come)
Zvingadai zvakaita sei kana tikashanda pamwe? (What would happen if we worked together?)

back: A person is not a forest that can be cleared by crying
culturalNote: Means that problems cannot be solved by complaining alone
usageExample: Ita chimwe chinhu, munhu haasi sango rinopera nokuchema (Do something, a person is not a forest that can be cleared by crying)

back: Don't boast about the mouse's tail
culturalNote: Warning against pride over small achievements
usageExample: Usazvikudze muswe wembeva, pachine zvakawanda zvausingazivi (Don't boast about the mouse's tail, there's much you don't know)
Ndinorara pamubhedha (I sleep on the bed)

culturalNote: Important in traditional ceremonies
Literally means 'my child' but used affectionately
usageExample: Mwanangu, uri sei? (My friend, how are you?)

back: memorial ceremony (lit: to strike the grave)
culturalNote: Important ceremony to honor deceased relatives
usageExample: Tichaita kurova guva mwedzi unouya (We will hold the memorial ceremony next month)

culturalNote: Important role in traditional weddings
usageExample: Mukwereti akasvika (The bride's attendant has arrived)
Ndakadya sadza nezuro (I ate sadza yesterday)
Ndiri kudya nhasi (I am eating now)

back: Prayer brings a snake out of its hole
culturalNote: Emphasizes the power of prayer
usageExample: Rega vanhu vanyengetere, chinamato chinobudisa nyoka mumwena (Let people pray, prayer brings a snake out of its hole)

culturalNote: Message of hope and perseverance
usageExample: Usashungurudzika, kune rimwe zuva rakanaka (Don't be troubled, there's another good day coming)

back: That which has horns is not wrapped up
culturalNote: Truth cannot be hidden
usageExample: Rine manyanga hariputirwi, chokwadi chichabuda (That which has horns is not wrapped up, the truth will come out)

back: To be vigilant (lit: to have two eyes)
usageExample: Iva nemaziso maviri pauri kufamba (Be vigilant when you're walking)

back: To take responsibility (lit: to take oneself on the back)
usageExample: Unofanira kuzvitora musana nemhuri yako (You must take responsibility for your family)
Ndinoshanda muhofisi (I work in an office)
Zvakafanana nokuti ari kurota (It's as if he's dreaming)
Uya pano pasina kukakavara (Come here without delay)
Sezvo zvisina kugadzikana, tinofanira kumirira (Since things are not settled, we must wait)
Ndinokumbira ruregerero pamusoro pechiitiko (I ask for forgiveness about the incident)
Ndakanzwa zvakare zvamakandiudza (I understood what you told me)
Nyarara unditeererere! (Be quiet and listen to me!)
Zvinoitika seiko kuti hapana akauya? (How does it happen that no one came?)
Zvisinei nezvazvo zvose, tinofanira kuenderera mberi (Regardless of all that, we must continue)
Ndakaberekerwa munaNdira (I was born in January)
Kukadzi kune mazuva mashoma (February has few days)
Chikoro chinotanga muna Kurume (School starts in March)
Munguva yezhizha kunopisa (In summer it's hot)

culturalNote: Important agricultural season
usageExample: Nguva yemvura yasvika (The rainy season has arrived)
Munguva yechando kunotonhora (In winter it's cold)

culturalNote: Central concept in Shona social organization
usageExample: Ndinoda kuenda kumusha (I want to go to the village)
Baba vari kumunda (Father is in the field)
Ndinochera munda (I am digging the field)

culturalNote: Main crop used to make sadza
Wisdom is highly valued in Shona culture
usageExample: Uchenjeri hwakakosha kupfuura mari (Wisdom is more valuable than money)

culturalNote: Respect is fundamental in Shona society
usageExample: Ruremekedzo ndiro pfuma yemunhu (Respect is a person's wealth)
